pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva, et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 2 illustrates each social layer of a proposed multi-layer network. In this network, the nodes represent people that remain consistent across layers, and the weighted connections indicate social contact that could potentially lead to infection based on the edge weight (a probability value within [0, 1)). The initial layer depicts home interactions and consists of groups with varying sizes, with each group being fully connected internally. These groups do not have external connections, essentially creating disconnected components that represent individual families. The distribution of family sizes considered in the study follows the Argentinean family size data for 2009, which includes information on family sizes ranging from 1 to 14 members. The probability of a family having sizes from 1 to 10 is taken into account when forming each group. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . A significant portion of the population in any country engages in work or economic activities, requiring interaction with others. Work plays a crucial role in social relations, especially during an epidemic. To model these interactions, we propose a generic layer connecting individuals aged 18 to 59, representing 60% of the total population in Argentina. Establishing connection rules that accurately reflect the diverse jobs and companies in the real world is complex. In our model, we consider random groups of sizes ranging from 5 to 30, uniformly distributed and internally connected, similar to the "home" layer shown in Figure 2(b) with n = 100. The transmission of the virus within these interconnected groups depends on edge weights, discussed further in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is a vital but crowded environment in most cities, facilitating geographical spread during an epidemic. The third layer in our model represents public transport users, accounting for 50% of the population on average. Random groups are formed with sizes between 10 and 40, each with fully connected nodes. The percentage of people using public transport in Argentina varies based on city size, with around 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities, averaging 1.2 hours per day.

prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: The proposed multi-layer network by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. (Physica A 564 (2021) 125498) consists of different social layers, each representing a specific type of interaction. The nodes in the network represent people, and the weighted connections signify social contact that could potentially lead to infection. The first layer simulates home interactions, with groups of varying sizes that are fully connected internally but do not have external connections to other groups. The structure of this layer is based on the distribution of family sizes in Argentina in 2010, ensuring that each family includes at least one adult. Another essential layer in the network represents work interactions, connecting people aged 18 to 59 who account for 60% of the population in Argentina. Work interactions are crucial in understanding social relations and their impact on epidemic scenarios. There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: . In Section 3.1.1, we delve into how the transmission of virus in a fully connected group of nodes is directly influenced by edge weights. Public transportation plays a crucial role in cities, as vehicles constantly moving around create opportunities for geographical spread during an epidemic. Our third proposed layer represents these collective transports for individuals without personal vehicles. In Argentina, the percentage of people using public transport varies based on city size, with 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], averaging around 1.2 hours of use per day. For our model, we consider an average participation rate of 50% in the ''transports'' layer, randomly sampling group sizes between 10 and 40 nodes that are fully connected. This approach accounts for the variability in public transport usage among different population groups.

author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study published in Physica A, Scabini, Ribas, Neiva, and colleagues investigated the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic. These actions include both the increase and decrease in cases, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The simulation began on a social network with all its layers and original infection probabilities. The infection started at a node with a degree closest to the average network degree and spread in daily iterations up to 300 days. The researchers assumed an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the start, resulting in an initial infection probability of β < 1. This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 23 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context:
. The activities that remain on these layers are services that cannot be stopped, such as essential services, activities that continue with increased precautionary measures while disregarding the quarantine. In this scenario, we first examine the impact of the β parameter on the overall shape of the epidemic. Figure 4(a) displays results for 4 different β values in relation to daily new cases and deaths, spanning up to 300 days after the initial infection. Higher infection rates lead to a more rapid spread of the disease and ultimately, a higher number of cases and deaths. However, the epidemic also ends sooner due to natural immunity among recovered individuals.

When comparing the model's output for the first 83 days with real data from the Brazilian epidemic (up to May 18), a better fit is observed with a β value of 0.3. This infection rate aligns well with the current situation where most people are wearing masks and taking additional precautions to prevent infection. Despite some variability, the model shows a significant similarity to the actual data. Differences in reported cases in the final days may be attributed to increased testing in Brazil or a decrease in isolation levels. The model assumes a consistent level of isolation based on initial observations, but data suggests that these levels are fluctuating. The number of diagnosed cases and deaths in the simulation may therefore be underestimated.

In terms of daily death rates, the average calculated by the model is higher than the official numbers. This disparity is likely due to underreporting and limited testing capacity. Further analysis is needed to fully comprehend the situation.

author: chunwei
pre_context: eiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 examines the impact of various actions on the broader epidemic situation, including changes in case numbers, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The study begins with a social network containing multiple layers and original infection probabilities. In this optimistic scenario, individuals are assumed to be aware of the virus from the onset, leading to a lower initial infection probability (β < 1) due to natural social distancing measures and increased precautions. The researchers found that this initial value of β resulted in outcomes closely aligned with the Argentine pandemic. After 27 days, a controlled quarantine resembling measures taken by Argentine states like Caba on March 24 is implemented. This quarantine involves removing certain layers of social contact and reducing interactions in various settings to 30% of their original levels (β = 0.09). Essential services continue with higher precautionary measures and some non-compliance with quarantine restrictions. The impact of the β parameter on the epidemic curve is then analyzed. Higher β values lead to faster disease spread and greater case and death numbers, but also accelerate the end of the epidemic due to natural immunity among recovered individuals.4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentine epidemic (up to May 20) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context:
causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected.The model demonstrates a notable level of similarity overall within its standard deviation. The larger discrepancies in diagnosed cases over the past ten days may be attributed to increased testing in Argentina or the consistent decline in isolation levels across the country (often below 50% in the past month) [43]. Our analysis assumed a consistent level of isolation similar to that seen in the early days following government decrees in Argentina, although data suggests these levels are constantly changing. Therefore, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in future simulations may be higher than reported in this paper (see the "keep isolation" scenario in the following section). In terms of daily death toll, the proposed models' average numbers are higher than official figures, which is to be expected given potentially higher rates of underdetection against the backdrop of fewer tests being conducted. We further examined the number of deaths in Argentina from January 1 to April 30, comparing data from 2019 and 2020; the results are displayed in Fig. 5. It is evident that a clear upward trend is observed post-February 26, the date of Argentina's first confirmed COVID-19 case, indicating a potentially significantly higher actual death toll compared to official reports.

Looking ahead, after the initial phase of the epidemic, we contemplate four potential courses of action to be taken after 90 days (May 26): a) Maintaining current isolation levels by taking no further action; b) Ending isolation and returning to normal activities (restoring initial network layers and weights); c) Resuming only work activities by restoring the initial probability of the network layer; or d) Intensifying isolation by halting remaining work and transport activities.

These scenarios included maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. As a result, only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases were diagnosed in the study.Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures).After 27 days since the first confirmed case, the initial isolation measures were implemented, including the closure of schools and religious activities, with work and transportation operating at only 30% capacity. After 90 days from the first case, various options were considered: maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation, ending isolation and returning to normal activities, or returning only work activities. The data suggests that maintaining current isolation levels may lead to prolonged spread, with anticipated peak around June 5 resulting in high daily new cases and deaths. It is estimated that hospitals may reach full capacity by June 11, but with efficient hospital management, the situation could still be managed. It is important to note that the definition of "keep isolation" in this case refers to maintaining social isolation levels above 50%, as observed at the start of the Argentinian quarantine. Argentina's current social isolation levels are consistently around 12%, which is significantly lower than what is considered necessary for effective containment measures.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In the study published in the International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health in 2021, an arbitrary constant κ is used in the model equation along with a modified logistic function to represent the transition in infection rates before and after the enforcement of mandatory mask wearing. The values of βs and βc are set to 1 and 0.4 respectively, representing the infection rates before and after full compliance with masking measures. The parameter t0 indicates the number of days after the first case when mask wearing enforcement begins. An example of the logistic function is shown in Figure 1, with t0 set to 89 in the case of Malaysia where mask wearing became compulsory 89 days after the first case was discovered. This model is applied in Scenarios 1 and 3 to represent the impact of mask wearing on infection rates. To account for gradual noncompliance with universal masking, Equation (9) is modified to include the gradual increase in infection rate βnc as individuals start to exhibit pandemic fatigue. The gradual noncompliance will result in a slower decrease in infection rates compared to the rapid decline seen when mask wearing is enforced. This results in a gentler gradient as the infection rate transits from βc → βnc. The gradients are tuned by the arbitrary constants k1 and k2, where k1 > k2. We further assume that the population are able to maintain compliance for a period of time before onset of noncompliance at t1, which may be triggered by an event, for example a change in the government's policy. 6. Results and Discussion 
6.1. Dynamics of Delay of Compulsory Mask Wearing 
By applying SEIR models to the scenarios outlined earlier, we were able to determine the Maximum Infected Values with varying delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, where there is full compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 depicts the impact of different enforcement timelines: (a) on the day the first case was detected; (b) after 50 days; (c) after 100 days; and (d) not enforced at all. 
It is evident from Figure 3 that earlier enforcement of mask wearing leads to a reduction in the Maximum Infected Value and an extended period to reach this peak. This is represented by a shift to the right in the Infected compartment and a lower peak value in the curve. As predicted by compartmental models, the infected number increases until reaching a global maximum, after which it decreases.

In Scenario 1, with complete compliance and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the impact of enforcing mask wearing on different days: (a) on the day the first COVID-19 case was detected in Malaysia, (b) after a 50-day delay, (c) after a 100-day delay, and (d) not enforced at all.

Figure 3 demonstrates that earlier enforcement of mask wearing not only reduces the Maximum Infected Value but also delays the peak infected cases. This is evident from the rightward shift of the peak infected compartment and a lower maximum value of the infected curve. The infected cases increase until reaching a global maximum, after which they decrease. For instance, with a 0-day delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is around 10.453% and peaks on day 291. With a 50-day delay, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.479% peaking on day 195. However, a 100-day delay results in a much higher maximum infected value of about 27.474% peaking on day 103, similar to scenarios where no masking is enforced.

author: chunwei
pre_context: The preprint of an agent-based epidemic model named REINA for COVID-19, aimed at identifying effective policies, was published on medRxiv on April 17, 2020. The copyright for this preprint belongs to the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv permission to display it under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The model was developed by authors from various institutions in Finland. The abstract discusses how countries have implemented different strategies to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.For example, South Korea started a vigorous campaign to suppress the virus by testing patients with respiratory symptoms and tracing and isolating all their contacts, and many European countries are trying to slow down the spread of the virus with varying degrees of shutdowns. There is clearly a need for a model that can realistically simulate different policy actions and their impacts on the disease and health care capacity in a country or a region. Specifically, there is a need to , i.e. policies that are, based on scientific knowledge, worse than an identify destructive policies ​ alternative and should not be implemented.
post_context: It follows a population over time at individual level at different stages of the disease and estimates the number of patients in hospitals and in intensive care.The model estimates death rates and counts based on available treatments, with various interventions such as physical isolation, testing, tracing, and controlling the entry of cases added on the timeline. The open-source code of the model can be accessed online. Results show different scenarios based on strategies implemented, including hospital capacity, mobility restrictions, testing, and isolation of positive cases and contacts. The model is based on the demographics of the Helsinki University Hospital region and begins on February 18, 2020. Note that this research has not been peer-reviewed and should not guide clinical practice.

author: chunwei
pre_context: The medRxiv preprint with the doi https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.09.20047498 was posted on April 17, 2020. The author/funder holds the copyright for this preprint, which has not undergone peer review, and has granted medRxiv a license to publicly display it under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The diagram in Figure 1 depicts the coronavirus agent model, with blue nodes representing different agent states, black arrows indicating transitions between states, red arrows showing infection pathways, and green boxes denoting targeted (isolation) and broad (mobility restriction) population groups experiencing varying degrees of social isolation. The model includes an "incubating" state for individuals who have the virus but have not yet exhibited symptoms, and the "infectious" state is further divided into four sub-states. The healthcare system parameters outlined in the model include the number of hospital beds, available hospital beds, number of intensive care beds, available intensive care beds, testing mode (lazy, active, aggressive), number of daily coronavirus tests, and length of testing queue.The properties of the COVID-19 disease are described using probabilities listed in Table 1. An important part of the model is the contact algorithm. Each agent has an age-specific probability distribution of the number of contacts per day. Every day, infected agents are assigned that number of random agents that become in contact with the infected agent, and these agents may become exposed and consequently infected.
post_context: .The model monitors the contacts of infected agents, allowing for the analysis of various testing and tracing strategies. The latest model version is capable of testing all symptomatic agents and then conducting contact tracing with a customizable level of accuracy. (Tuomisto et al., 2020)

post_context: vs 5300 deaths in a year) and lower restriction day index (72 vs 111 RDI) than the one aiming at mitigation.The healthcare system in this scenario requires fewer intensive care units (300 as compared to 1050), resulting in lower healthcare intensity. Several scenarios were examined, including one that showed the epidemic being suppressed by the end of 2020 with a permanent implementation of strict mobility restrictions (50%). Two other scenarios, which involved mild restrictions from the beginning (25%) or a relaxation of restrictions before summer (to 30%), predicted a rapid increase in the epidemic. The model output displayed in Figure 2 illustrates a mitigation strategy with new hospital beds, 30-40% mobility restriction, and testing only severe cases. The simulation results indicated 660,000 recovered patients after one year. Figure 3 shows a suppression strategy with initial 50% and later 20-25% mobility reduction, aggressive testing of mild cases, and contact tracing, resulting in 77,000 recovered patients after one year. These results are from single simulation runs, not averages of ensembles.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Study on the Evaluation of Transmission Risk of 2019-nCoV and Its Impact on Public Health Measures by Sanyi Tang, Yanni Xiao, Biao Tang, Xia Wang, Qian Li, Nicola Luigi Bragazzi, and Jianhong Wu from Xi'an Jiaotong University and York University discusses the assessment of the transmission risk of the virus and its implications for public health interventions.School of Mathematics and Information Science, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710119, China; xiawang@snnu.edu.cn (X.W. ); sanyitang219@hotmail.com (S.T.) School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Wuhan, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity.
post_context: The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the control reproduction number may be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions like intensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation can effectively reduce the transmission risk and control reproduction number. The impact of travel restrictions, similar to those implemented in Wuhan for 2019-nCoV, on infections in Beijing is nearly as effective as increasing quarantine measures by 100 thousand baseline value. It is crucial to evaluate the effectiveness and duration of the costly and resource-intensive measures taken by Chinese authorities to combat 2019-nCoV. With the most stringent measures in place, it is anticipated that the outbreak will peak within two weeks (since 23 January 2020) with a significantly low peak value. Implementing travel restrictions (preventing exposed individuals from entering Beijing) could reduce the number of infected individuals by 91.14% in seven days compared to scenarios without travel restrictions. Keywords: coronavirus; infection management and control; travel restriction; mathematical model; SEIR model Introduction: Coronaviruses, members of the Coronaviridae family, are enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses that typically cause mild respiratory infections but can be fatal. Since their discovery in 1965, there have been three major outbreaks caused by highly pathogenic coronaviruses, including the SARS outbreak in 2003 in China, the MERS outbreak in 2012 in Saudi Arabia, and the MERS outbreak in South Korea in 2015.

post_context: (95% CI 5.71–7.23). Sensitivity analyses indicate that implementing interventions such as intensive contact tracing, quarantine, and isolation can effectively reduce the transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. The impact of travel restrictions, as seen in Hubei, is comparable to increasing quarantine measures significantly. It is crucial to evaluate the effectiveness of costly measures taken by Chinese authorities in preventing and controlling the spread of 2019-nCoV, as well as determining the duration of their implementation. With the strictest measures in place, it is projected that the outbreak will peak within two weeks since January 23, 2020, with a significantly lower peak value. Additionally, implementing travel restrictions in Beijing can lead to a 91.14% decrease in the number of infected individuals within seven days. The study focuses on coronavirus infection management and control, including travel restrictions, through mathematical modeling such as the SEIR model. The family of Coronaviridae consists of enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses that cause primarily mild respiratory infections, although they can be fatal. The emergence of highly pathogenic coronaviruses has led to major outbreaks such as SARS in 2003, MERS in 2012, and the MERS outbreak in 2015.

text: The model was calibrated using data from the state of Ohio in the U.S. Ohio is one of the few states producing detailed daily reports of COVID-19 confirmed cases, COVID-19 related cumulative hospitalizations, intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and deaths per county.
author: chunwei
pre_context: There is significant geographic variation in the intensity and transmission range of respiratory infections, influenced by the uneven distribution of vulnerable populations and risk factors that either promote or hinder the spread of pathogens (Green et al., 2016; Caini et al., 2018; Park et al., 2020; Real and Biek, 2007; Sloan et al., 2011). This is particularly important considering disparities in healthcare system capacity which can greatly impact disease outcomes (Ji et al., 2020). The COVID-19 pandemic has not affected all regions of the U.S. equally, with the Northeast reporting higher cases and deaths (van Dorn et al., 2020). The reasons for these regional disparities are not currently well understood.Preliminary  studies  have  identified  socioeconomic  (e.g higher  population of ethnic minorities), health-related (e.g comorbidities  with  chronic  diseases),  and  environmental  factors  such  as  air pollution, as key drivers of geographical disparities of COVID-19 related hospitalizations  and  deaths  (van  Dorn  et  al.,  2020;  Wu  et  al.,  2020; COVID, 2020). In a previous study we found that the spatial distribution of these factors along with other spatial attributes such as airport and road connectivity were linked to the geospatial disparities of COVID-19 related risk of mortality in the U.S (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020). Understanding the local variation in disease transmission dynamics under heterogeneous geospatial attributes is a crucial step in developing more effective strategies for mitigating risk of infection in vulnerable communities. Therefore,  in  this  study,  we  built  a  spatially-explicit mathematical  model  to  predict  the  county-level  spatial  dynamics  of COVID-19 epidemic in a region.
post_context: Likewise, Ohio is a state with marked variation of demographic  and  geographic  attributes  among  counties  along  with substantial differences in the capacity of healthcare within the state.Our goal is to predict the spatial and temporal trends of the COVID-19 pandemic in Ohio based on healthcare capacity distribution. To achieve this, we developed a spatial mathematical model that incorporates geographic connectivity information at the county level. The model, known as the Susceptible-Infected-Hospitalized-Recovered-Dead (SIHRD) COVID-19 model, classifies the population into different groups and stratifies them based on connectivity index for each county. The dynamics of disease transmission and infection progression were modeled for each spatial risk group using seven epidemiological compartments within the SIHRD model. This approach takes into account the variability in the risk of exposure and the impact of public health interventions on disease spread.

Counties in Ohio with higher air transportation connectivity experienced a faster spread of COVID-19 compared to neighboring counties with high road connectivity or more isolated rural counties. This geographical difference in infection severity was not solely due to population distribution but also to spatial attributes like transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed cases were in five counties (Lake Erie, Brentwood, Possible location: Lucas, Kansas, Birmingham, and Mountain Top) with an average infection rate of 274 cases per 100,000 people. These counties have high population density and serve as local air hubs, receiving over 10,000,000 passengers annually. The influx of travelers through airports in these counties can lead to an increase in locally imported infections, accelerating the spread of the virus.

In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. We also identified marked differences in the geographical distribution of the critical healthcare capacity of the state. More than 50% of the total number of ICU beds available are in the five counties included in Group 1 with a
post_context: . On the contrary, only 7% of ICU beds in the state are located in the 31 rural and less connected counties, amounting to 10 ICU beds per 100,000 individuals. Despite these disparities in critical healthcare resources, our analysis suggests that the unique disease dynamics in these areas, with lower transmission rates, prevented overwhelming the critical care systems. If the non-pharmaceutical interventions enforced in mid-March 2020 were continued after early May, only 27% of the state's critical care capacity would be utilized, including the 10 counties without ICU-equipped hospitals. Three additional counties, Clermont, Delaware, and Lawrence, would reach over 50% capacity under these conditions. However, relaxing interventions by 50% would lead to reaching 61% of the maximum capacity eight weeks later, with areas experiencing more intense transmission saturating their critical care capacity sooner. Counties with higher transmission rates would reach 94% capacity eight weeks after easing interventions, while rural and less connected counties in Group 4 would have slower infection spread and less impact on critical care capacity.

The counties in Group 4 have a significantly lower critical care response compared to Group 1, which reduces the risk of critical care saturation in these areas. It is projected that only 55% of the maximum critical healthcare capacity in these counties will be reached eight weeks after the easing of social distancing measures. Additionally, eight counties in Group 4 do not have hospitals with ICU beds, with counties like Adams, Champaign, and Seneca expected to exceed 60% of their maximum critical care capacity. Therefore, it is crucial to prioritize strategies to enhance critical care response against the COVID-19 pandemic in Ohio in these less connected counties and air hub areas.Our study has several limitations worth noting. For simplification, we generated a connectivity index based only in one geospatial attribute in which airports and main roads were used as a connectivity index for each county. Other potential geospatial and population characteristics might influence transmission dynamics and improve estimated disease trajectories,  but  inclusion  of  these  factors  can  substantially  increase model complexity. post_context: ,  which  were  counties  that  experienced  explosive  confined COVID-19 outbreaks occurring in different prisons.Nevertheless, localized outbreaks have the potential to significantly impact critical care capacity in affected areas and play a crucial role in disease transmission. It is important to note that the COVID-19 model discussed in this study was based solely on data from Ohio. The pandemic consists of multiple sub-epidemics varying in intensity, even within the same country. COVID-19 outbreaks have occurred at different times and in different regions within the U.S., with each state implementing varying control measures that could lead to significant differences in disease dynamics. Therefore, it is essential to evaluate the model's performance using data from diverse locations. Despite these limitations, this study presents one of the earliest spatiotemporal models of COVID-19 transmission, which can simulate spatial disparities in outcomes such as confirmed cases, hospitalizations, ICU admissions, and more.

text: In close communication with Cornell University's administration, we conducted a simulation-based analysis in summer 2020 using a compartmental Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, and Recovered model with multiple subpopulations
author: chunwei
pre_context: Despite facing similar circumstances, certain US states and national governments have taken vastly different approaches to the pandemic. Simulation-based epidemic models offer a potential solution to this uncertainty, allowing for predictions tailored to specific locations and strategies. While these models may not perfectly reflect reality due to inherent variables and the potential for exponential growth, they can still assist in decision-making. This article showcases how simulation models aided in the design of effective COVID-19 interventions at Cornell University, demonstrating their potential value in guiding decisions at other universities as well.(The use of epidemic models in the presence of significant parameter uncertainty is also discussed in, for example, ref. 15. In such settings, clear communication of uncertainties is key; see, for example, ref. 16).)
post_context: ; see refs.Our research formed the basis for Cornell University's decision to resume in-person instruction on their Ithaca campus in fall 2020. Our recommendations were also used to establish an asymptomatic screening program that played a crucial role in Cornell's overall strategy. As a result of our modeling, the majority of students were welcomed back to campus for the 2020-2021 academic year, with 75% opting to return. The surveillance program employed pooled PCR testing based on our modeling recommendations and utilized anterior nares (AN) sampling over nasopharyngeal (NP) sampling for greater comfort and compliance. This program was made possible through a collaborative effort with a local healthcare provider and the establishment of a new COVID-19 testing laboratory. Adjustments were made to the strategy for subsequent semesters based on our modeling, including increased testing frequencies for certain groups and adaptations to account for new variants and vaccination rates. Despite facing challenges such as the Delta variant and changes in policies, Cornell reported fewer than 1,044 infections among students and staff during the 2020-2021 academic year, a lower number compared to some similar institutions offering only virtual instruction. Our modeling approach focuses on identifying key input parameters that can effectively control epidemics, guiding decision-making for successful infection prevention strategies.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: A prior probability distribution for parameters was established using independent normal distributions, with the mean and variance selected to align with known plausible ranges for each parameter. The use of a multivariate normal distribution as a prior allowed for modeling and tractability concerns, ensuring a unimodal prior with ellipsoidal contours for analysis. Random sets of parameters were drawn from this prior, accounting for parameter uncertainty and forming a prior distribution over infections. Testing twice a week is typically effective for infection control, but large outbreaks may occur under certain parameter settings. To assess the impact of interventions like testing in the face of parameter uncertainty, a one-dimensional family of parameter configurations was developed with varying levels of pessimism regarding infection numbers.This family of parameter configurations is indexed by a pessimism level between zero and one, with larger levels corresponding to parameter configurations with more infections. The parameter configuration at pessimism level q is the most likely configuration under the prior for which median infections is equal to the q quantile of infections under the prior, assuming that infections for a given parameter configuration are given by the previously fitted linear model. Within this family, we name two for more frequent use, given in Fig. 1F: the nominal and pessimistic scenarios, corresponding to pessimism levels 0.5 and
post_context: , respectively.In plots, we refer to the pessimistic residential scenario to distinguish it from other pessimistic outcomes in Results D. The pessimistic scenario significantly changes certain parameters, increasing asymptomatic ratio and transmission rate while decreasing test sensitivity and contact tracing effectiveness. These changes have the greatest impact on infections. The assumptions of linearity in creating these scenarios were tested by comparing the median number of infections under various pessimistic scenarios against a quantile of median infections, with results showing strong agreement. Simulated infections using 2x/week testing at different levels of pessimism were plotted, showing that testing can help keep infections below 1,000 in most cases with some parameter configurations leading to rapid infection growth. Additional testing can reduce this risk. High test frequency can keep infections low even at high levels of pessimism. These results were shared in public reports and Cornell Faculty Senate meetings, including both nominal and pessimistic scenarios similar to those discussed here.

NPIs showed significant effects on model predictions, while vaccination rates also had a notable impact on disease spread. Dosing intervals and vaccine escape rates had smaller effects. Effective vaccine deployment was found to be crucial in combating a pandemic, with prioritizing the first dose being advisable if vaccine supply is limited. Following the lockdown of Nanjing on January 23rd, 2020, travel restrictions were imposed in most regions across the country, leading to improved case confirmation speed through new coronavirus nucleic acid-based detection technologies. In light of the strong prevention and control measures in China, the previously estimated basic reproduction number is no longer suitable for assessing the epidemic trend. Therefore, updated data is used to parameterize the proposed model (Tang et al., 2020) and re-evaluate the transmission risk of 2019-nCov.

To estimate the effective daily reproduction ratio, the time-dependent contact rate c(t) and dI(t) are initially obtained (Fig. 1(a)). By using discrete values of contact rate c(t) and diagnose rate dI(t), the effective daily reproduction ratio, (t), can be calculated as shown in Fig. 1(b). It is observed that under strict prevention and control measures, the effective daily reproduction ratio Rd has remained below 1 since January 26th, 2020, indicating a decline in new infections. Notably, the effective daily reproduction ratio decreased from January 23rd, 2020 to January 25th, 2020, as a result of various restrictive measures, including the lockdown of Nanjing, contact tracing, and quarantine.

This means that the period of diagnosis (1/dI(t)) decreases as time progresses, following a specific formula: 1/dI(t) = 1/dI0 + 1/dIf * e^-r^2t, where dI0 represents the initial diagnosis rate, dIf is the fastest rate of diagnosis reached at an exponential rate, and r^2 is a constant related to available resources. By incorporating time-dependent coefficients into a previously derived formula, we can define a function (λ) to calculate the effective daily reproduction ratio, indicating the daily reproduction number of new infections caused by a single infected individual per day during their infectious period. Data on cumulative laboratory-confirmed cases of 2019-nCov were obtained from the National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China for analysis. The data information includes the cumulative confirmed cases, the cumulative number of deaths, newly confirmed cases and the cumulative number of cured cases, which are reported daily by the National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China. The results of the estimation are presented in Table 1.

Following the lockdown of City of Nanjing on January 23rd, 2020, most regions in the country implemented travel restrictions and improved case confirmation speed through new detection technologies. Given the strengthening prevention and control measures in China, the previously estimated basic reproduction number is no longer sufficient to forecast the epidemic trend. Thus, we updated the data to parameterize the model (Tang et al., 2020) and re-evaluate the transmission risk of 2019-nCov. By analyzing the time-dependent contact rate c(t) and dI(t) as shown in Fig. 1(a), we determined the effective daily reproduction ratio, θ(t), presented in Fig. 1(b). It is observed that under strict prevention measures, the effective daily reproduction ratio Rd has been below 1 since January 26th, 2020, indicating a decline in new infections. Additionally, the effective daily reproduction ratio decreased between January 23rd and January 25th, 2020, due to various restrictive measures such as the City of Nanjing lockdown and contact tracing.

The epidemics doubling time was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). The dynamics transmission model by Shen and coworkers (Shen, Peng, Xiao, & Zhang, 2020) predicted 8042 (95% CI 4199e11,884) infections and 898 (95% CI 368e1429) deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78%). pre_context: According to Wu and colleagues (2020), using a nowcasting and forecasting approach, an estimated basic reproductive number of 2.68 (95% credible interval or CrI 2.47e2.86) was calculated, with around 75,815 individuals (95% CrI 37,304e130,330) infected in Wuhan as of January 25, 2020. The doubling time of the epidemic was found to be 6.4 days (95% CrI 5.8e7.1). A transmission model by Shen et al. (2020) predicted 8042 (95% CI 4199e11,884) infections and 898 (95% CI 368e1429) deaths, with a fatality rate of 11.02% (95% CI 9.26e12.78%). The authors also calculated a basic reproduction number of  4.71 (95% CI 4.50e4.92), which decreased to 2.08 (95% CI 1.99e2.18) by January 22, 2020. Based on these estimates, the pandemic outbreak is expected to significantly decrease within 77 days (95% CI 75e80) from its start. Additionally, the researchers found that reducing the time from illness/symptom onset to isolation by one day could lead to a 72-84% decrease in peak population size and a 68-80% decrease in cumulative infected cases and deaths.The study by Majumder and Mandl (Majumder & Mandl, 2020) utilized the "Incidence Decay and Exponential Adjustment" (IDEA) model and led to an estimate of the reproduction number in the range of 2.0e3.1. Finally, Riou and Althaus (Riou & Althaus, 2020), using a stochastic model simulating epidemics trajectories, computed a reproduction number of 2.2 (90% high density interval 1.4e3.8). Using statistical approaches, namely exponential growth and maximum likelihood techniques, Liu and colleagues (Liu et al., 2020) estimated the value of the reproduction number ranging from 2.90 (95% CI 2.32e3.63) to 2.92 (95% CI 2.28e3.67). Zhang and Wang (Zhang & Wang, 2020), employing a Bayesian framework to infer time-calibrated phylogeny from 33 available genomic sequences, found that the time of the most recent common ancestor (MRCA) was December 17th, 2019 (95% highest posterior density interval from December 7th, 2019 to December 23rd, 2019) and that the value of the
post_context: .Various factors such as methodological issues, model assumptions, choice of parameters, dataset used, and estimation period can account for the different findings observed in studies on the transmission of the coronavirus outbreak. Comparing updated versions of these investigations revealed variations in the reproduction number, reflecting the evolving dynamics of the outbreak and case reporting. The reproduction number trended upwards over time in correlation with increasing reported cases, with sensitivity and dependency on the estimation period and available data. It is important to note that the accuracy of findings is heavily influenced by the model frameworks and data analysis techniques employed.

text: By using time-dependent contact and diagnose rates we refit our proposed dynamics transmission model to the data available until January 29th, 2020 and re-estimated the daily reproduction number, which implies the evolving transmission risk.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Research on disease modeling, based on previous studies of the SARS outbreak, suggests that the current 2019 n-CoV situation is comparable to that of SARS. However, in this case, Wuhan serves as the epicenter with a large population, leading to the spread of the virus throughout the entire country. The evolving outbreak situation highlights the importance of interventions and resources provided to frontline workers and patients. The outcome of controlling the spread is influenced by factors such as speed of diagnoses and hospitalizations.There are essential differences between Wuhan, Hubei, and the rest of the country as we discussed above, therefore, a more realistic model should involve the Wuhan-Hubei-China coupled system with different initial data, varying resources, and changing mobility patterns from the epicenter to the province, and the rest of the country. It is also important to mention that we only used the data of cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 to calibrate our model. Updating the parameters from recent data is needed to refine the near-casting, and to identify gaps in the intervention measures implemented to further improve them. Conclusions Due to variation in the control strategies with the time and the improvement of detection of the new coronavirus cases, we updated our previous estimations on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV.
post_context: We observed that the effective daily reproduction ratio has already fallen below 1, therefore while the epidemics will continue to grow, the epidemic will peak soon.Accurately forecasting the epidemic trend and predicting the peak time requires real-time data and knowledge of implementation and available resources to facilitate public health interventions. This research was funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Canada Research Chair Program. We appreciate support from various organizations, including the Tianyuan Mathematical Center and the Fields Institute for Research in Mathematical Sciences. References include studies on SARS and the 2019-nCoV coronavirus.

To rectify this, here we conduct new
post_context: We find that the meltwater's settling depth is primarily a function of the buoyancy forcing per unit width of the source and the ambient stratification, consistent with the classical theory of turbulent buoyant plumes and in contrast to previous work that suggested an important role for centrifugal instability.Our findings emphasize the important role of localized variability in stratification in explaining the fluctuation in vertical meltwater distribution near Pine Island Glacier. Due to the diverse mass loss rates and environmental conditions across Antarctic ice shelves, it is essential to dynamically parameterize meltwater settling depth for accurate simulations of high-latitude climate in a warming world. This study discusses the potential development of such parameterization and the challenges that still need to be addressed. Key topics covered include oceanography, Antarctica, glaciers, snowmelt/icemelt, and climate change.

BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352  https://doi.org/10.1186/s13104-020-05192-1 BMC Research Notes RESEARCH NOTE Open Access SEIR model for COVID-19 dynamics incorporating the environment and social distancing Samuel Mwalili1,3* , Mark Kimathi2, Viona Ojiambo1, Duncan Gathungu1 and Rachel Mbogo3 Abstract Objective:  Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic respiratory illness spreading from person-to-person caused by a novel coronavirus and poses a serious public health risk. The goal of this study was to apply a modified susceptible-exposed-infectious-recovered (SEIR) compartmental mathematical model for prediction of COVID-19 epidemic dynamics incorporating pathogen in the environment and interventions.
post_context: Results:  We found an R0 of 2.03, implying that the pandemic will persist in the human population in the absence of strong control measures.Results from simulations of different scenarios suggest that failing to adhere to social distancing and hygiene measures can have devastating effects on the human population. The model demonstrates that quarantining contacts and isolating cases can effectively stop the spread of the novel coronavirus. Introduction: Coronaviruses encompass a wide range of viruses that can lead to mild illnesses like the common cold or more severe diseases such as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). The emergence of the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) in Wuhan, China at the end of 2019 resulted in a global health crisis as it rapidly spread around the world, prompting the World Health Organization to declare COVID-19 a global pandemic in February 2020. The aim of this study was to create a modified SEIR compartmental mathematical model to predict the dynamics of the COVID-19 epidemic under various intervention scenarios, ultimately providing insight into the most effective measures to reduce the risk of transmission. Previous research has focused on mathematical modeling of the novel coronavirus, with some studies utilizing models from previous outbreaks like Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) to estimate transmission rates during different intervention periods.

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context:
into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The presence of the pathogen in the environment is represented as P(t). Therefore, for the human population, the equation N (t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t) holds true. Research has demonstrated that COVID-19 can spread in two ways: from human to human and from the environment to humans. Infected individuals, both asymptomatic IA(t) and symptomatic IS(t), transmit the virus to susceptible persons S(t) through close contact. Additionally, when infected individuals cough or sneeze without proper precautions, the virus is released into the environment. As the pathogen P(t) can survive in the environment for several days, individuals in close proximity to the contaminated environment are at risk of exposure, particularly at the onset of the COVID-19 outbreak before hygiene measures are established. 
In the transmission of the disease, susceptible individuals initially move to the exposed population E(t) due to the incubation period. The exposed individuals then transition to either asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) infected population. P(t) represents the quantity of pathogens present when humans interact at time t. The majority of infected individuals recover and transition to the recovered human population R(t). The compartmental model illustrating the interaction between the human population and the environmental pathogens is shown in Fig. 1. The parameters used in the transmission model are detailed in Table 1, resulting in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations. Fig. 1 SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission displays the interaction between humans (SEIR, yellow shade) and pathogens (P, green shade).

pre_context: Mwalili and colleagues conducted a study exploring the complex interactions between humans and the environment in the spread of SARS-CoV-2. They developed a mathematical model to simulate the transmission of the virus, considering two populations - humans as hosts and pathogens. The model divided the human population into susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic infectious, symptomatic infectious, and recovered individuals. It was observed that the virus can be transmitted through human-to-human contact and from the environment to humans. Infected individuals, both asymptomatic and symptomatic, can spread the virus to susceptible persons through close contact or by coughing and sneezing without precautions.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. In  the  process  of  disease  spread,  the  susceptible  individual first moves to the exposed population E(t) since the host has an incubation period[5]. The exposed individual  moves  to  either  asymptomatic  IA(t)  or  symptomatic  IS(t)  infectious  population. post_context: respectively.Health experts and governments have been recommending practicing social distancing to reduce contact with infectious individuals during the outbreak. In our model, we suggest a way to calculate new infections by considering interactions with infected individuals and the environment. The equilibrium points and basic reproduction number of the SEIR-P model are determined by solving relevant equations. The disease-free equilibrium point occurs when there are no infectious or exposed individuals in the population. The basic reproduction number, denoted as R0, indicates the average number of secondary infections caused by an individual in a susceptible population. Calculating R0 using the next generation matrix approach involves evaluating derivatives at the disease-free equilibrium point.

post_context: and also the virus in the environment (P).After the latency period, if the epidemic is not controlled, the number of infected individuals increases rapidly, exceeding the capacity of 8000 hospital beds. Of the total infected population, 30% are asymptomatic or exhibit mild symptoms. The simulation study uses model parameters as shown in Table 1. Symptomatic individuals are considered to be more infectious than asymptomatic individuals, leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 in various settings such as households, workplaces, schools, and public transport. This results in a surge of cases confirmed between 10 and 35 days, as shown in Figures 2a and 2b. The model takes into account constants α1 and α2, which represent the frequency of acquiring the virus from the environment or infected individuals, respectively. When α1 is higher, there is a greater risk of getting infected from the environment, leading to more exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals. Conversely, with a higher α2 value, there is a greater risk of getting infected from an individual rather than the environment. The model depicts that when α2 = 0.05, susceptible individuals disappear by the 23rd day due to rapid spread of infection, which then decreases from the 25th day onwards. The number of infected individuals is lower when α2 = 0.05 compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Control measures such as social distancing are crucial in mitigating the spread of the virus.

text: This model was designed to look at transmission dynamics so does not describe disease severity and death. Given we  made  assumptions  of  the  parameters  at  onset  of  the pandemic, there is a possibility that the model may overestimate the pandemic at later period of time.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The study data presented in Table 1 indicates that symptomatic individuals (IS) are assumed to be more infectious than asymptomatic individuals (IA), leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 through various contacts. This results in a surge of the virus in environments such as workplaces, schools, food sources, and public transport, resulting in a higher number of confirmed cases of the coronavirus within 10 to 35 days. The model considers constants α1 and α2 as reciprocal values representing the frequency of acquiring COVID-19 from the environment and infected individuals, respectively. When α1 is set at 0.05, indicating a higher risk of infection from a contaminated environment, the number of exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals increases. Conversely, when α2 is set at 0.05, indicating higher chances of infection from an individual as compared to a contaminated environment, the number of susceptible individuals decreases rapidly. By the 23rd day, the number of susceptible individuals is depleted when α2 is set at 0.05 due to rapid infection rates. Figures 2d-f provide further detail on the progression of the outbreak within the first 20 days.Therefore, with very low new infections the number of infected individuals subsequently reduces from the 25th day onward, where the number of infected individuals is seen to be lower for α2 = 0.05 , as compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Discussion The  model  shows  that  control  measures  such  as  social distancing,  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  frequent  hand washing and limiting non-essential travel needed to avoid a large COVID-19 epidemic. There is a growing concern that  this  disease  could  continue  to  ravage  the  human population globally since many aspects of the COVID-19 are yet to be discovered, which also poses a challenge to the long-term mathematical modeling of the disease. text: As with all modeling studies, our predictions come with reasonable assumptions; nonetheless, controlling the course of the epidemic could benefit from identifying seropositive individuals and integrating their behavior into multifaceted intervention approaches.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Intervention in serology through a shield immunity approach is summarized in Table 1. This policy outlines the methods for shielding against transmission based on individuals' susceptibility, infectiousness, and recovery status in relation to virus and antibody presence.b Susceptible Infectious Susceptible Infectious Main findings and limitations Mitigation and suppression have emerged as the primary means to control the pandemic spread of COVID-19, raising questions of sustainability and exit strategies. Complementary to mitigation and suppression, we have proposed a 'shield immunity' model of intervention that leverages serological tests to identify and deploy recovered individuals who have developed protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is essential to identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered and are immune (in the near term) to SARS-CoV-2. Several scenarios have been explored that show substantive decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline given enhanced interactions with recovered individuals that reduce the risk of transmission.
post_context: Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19.Questions still linger about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, but identifying and utilizing recovered individuals strategically presents an opportunity to decrease transmission for the greater good. Implementing widespread serological testing initiatives is crucial for proactive strategies to end the COVID-19 pandemic and facilitate economic recovery, with the aim of fewer than 25% of the population being infected, compared to the expected 90% without protective measures. Our core shielding model serves as a foundation for applying to COVID-19, highlighting the conservative benefits of shielding. However, detailed models on mixing and substitutions could provide further insights, especially in spatially explicit areas or network settings. In this study, we adapt our shield immunity model to the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic, simplifying the population as susceptible, exposed, asymptomatic infectious, symptomatic infectious, and recovered individuals. Certain symptomatic cases will require hospitalization, categorized as subacute or critical/acute requiring intensive care. We project a portion of critical cases to result in fatalities. Age-specific risks are based on data from studies in the United Kingdom and the United States. Our comprehensive model, incorporating shield immunity, differs from traditional SIR models with social distancing measures.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The primary methods of controlling the spread of COVID-19 are mitigation and suppression, but there are concerns about their long-term effectiveness. In addition to these methods, we suggest a 'shield immunity' approach that utilizes serological tests to identify and utilize recovered individuals with protective antibodies. Serological testing is crucial for identifying those who are immune to SARS-CoV-2 in the short term. Our simulations show significant reductions in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths when recovered individuals are included in intervention strategies. While our predictions are based on certain assumptions, incorporating seropositive individuals into intervention strategies could help control the epidemic.Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19. Although questions remain about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, strategic identification and deployment of recovered individuals represents an opportunity to reduce transmission for the collective good. Initiating large-scale serological testing initiatives is key to proactive approaches to end the COVID-19 pandemic and enable economic re-engagement. ensuring  the  final  outbreak  concludes  with  less  than  25%  of  the population  having  been  infected  compared  to  the  expectation  of
post_context: in the absence of shielding.We base our application to COVID-19 on our core shielding model, which embodies the conservative benefits of shielding. However, more detailed mixing and substitution models may lead to different variations, such as in spatially explicit areas or on networks. In this study, we apply our shield immunity model to the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic, considering a population made up of susceptible, exposed, infectious asymptomatically, infectious symptomatically, and recovered individuals. We also consider subsets of symptomatic cases that may require hospital care, categorized as subacute and critical cases. The model takes into account age-stratified risks of hospitalization and acute cases. Unlike traditional SIR models with interventions like social distancing, our model reduces the transmission rate by considering shield immunity and the proportion of recovered individuals. The model assumes that all recovered individuals have immunity, but only a subset can enable interaction substitutions. It also assumes that individuals in the circulating pool do not interact with hospitalized patients.

post_context: in the baseline scenario without shielding (Fig.We also investigated 'flexible' and 'fixed' shielding as potential alternative mechanisms for interaction substitution in our study. A flexible shielding mechanism adjusts the interaction rates of recovered individuals by a factor of (1 + α) compared to other individuals, while maintaining the total contact rate the same as the baseline. Conversely, a fixed shielding mechanism increases the interaction rates of recovered individuals by a factor of (1 + α) compared to the baseline rate, while keeping the total contact rate the same as the baseline. Results from Extended Data Fig. 1 show that shielding is effective in these alternative scenarios and may even be more effective. For instance, with fixed shielding and α = 3, recovered individuals have four times as many contacts compared to before the intervention.

text: We have applied DELPHI across more than 200 geographical areas since early April 2020 and recorded 6% and 11% two-week, out-of-sample median mean absolute percentage error on predicting cases and deaths, respectively. DELPHI compares favorably with other top COVID-19 epidemiological models and predicted in 2020 the large-scale epidemics in many areas, including the United States, United Kingdom, and Russia, months in advance.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The link to the journal "OPERATIONS RESEARCH" for January-February 2023, Volume 71, Issue 1 is: https://pubsonline.informs.org/journal/opre184–201 ISSN 0030-364X (print), ISSN 1526-5463 (online) Crosscutting Areas Forecasting COVID-19 and Analyzing the Effect of Government Interventions Michael Lingzhi Li,a Hamza Tazi Bouardi,a Omar Skali Lami,a Thomas A. Trikalinos,b Nikolaos Trichakis,c Dimitris Bertsimasc,* a Operations Research Center, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139; b Center for Evidence Synthesis in Health, Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island 02912; c Sloan School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142 *Corresponding author Contact: mlli@mit.edu, oskali@mit.edu, (TAT); ntrichakis@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8208-3035 (OSL); thomas_trikalinos@brown.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8324-9148 (NT); dbertsim@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2456-4834 (MLL); htazi@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3990-1848 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1985-1003 (DB) https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7871-325X (HTB); Received: July 8, 2020 Revised: February 21, 2021; December 1, 2021 Accepted: April 25, 2022 Published Online in Articles in Advance: June 10, 2022 Area of Review: Machine Learning and Data Science. https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306 Copyright: © 2022 INFORMS Abstract. We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context: We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.Initially, we assess the impact of government interventions on the spread of the pandemic. Our analysis indicates that without any interventions, over 14 million people would have died by May 17, 2020. Implementing interventions just one week earlier could have prevented 280,000 deaths globally. Mass gathering restrictions and school closures were found to be the most effective measures, leading to significant reductions in infection rates. Stay-at-home orders resulted in the highest reduction across countries that implemented them. Additionally, we demonstrate how our DELPHI model can forecast future COVID-19 cases under different government policies, showcasing its utility for decision-making. Janssen Pharmaceuticals used this analysis to choose trial locations for its single-dose vaccine candidate. The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, with over 530 million cases and 6.3 million deaths as of June 1st, 2022, is considered one of the deadliest outbreaks. DELPHI, developed in March 2020, builds on existing models to provide comprehensive predictions, accounting for deaths, underreported infections, and the impact of interventions. consistently relied upon by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for forecasting. Additional information can be found in the e-companion available at https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306. Keywords: epidemiology, modeling, infectious diseases, government interventions.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Li et al. (2022) conducted a study on forecasting COVID-19 under different government interventions. Their research, published in Operations Research, analyzed the impact of various policy categories implemented worldwide. The study found that the most effective policy category was the stringent stay-at-home order, which led to the largest decrease in the residual infection rate. It was observed that more restrictive policies were often implemented later but resulted in greater reductions in the spread of the virus. The findings are summarized in Table 4, showing the implementation length and effectiveness of each policy category.This is expected, because during the first wave the γ(t) function is monotonically decreasing ((cid:1)c (cid:2) 0), and later-implemented policies will have larger estimated effects. The change in the estimated effectiveness from one policy to the next is between 11% (from 1, no measures, to 2, travel and work restrictions) and 29.9% (from 2 to 3, mass gathering, school, travel, and work restrictions). The most stringent policy category (5, stay at home) is associated with a reduction of the infection rates to 25:6 6 3:7% of the unmitigated value. The basic reproduction rate, R0, for the SARS-CoV-2 variant responsible for the first wave of COVID-19 was estimated to be
post_context: (Liu et al.In 2020, Zhang et al. discussed the importance of R0 in measuring the spread of infections in a population. R0 indicates the average number of new infections caused by one infected individual in a susceptible population. Effective control of an epidemic requires reducing the reproduction rate, Rt, below 1. Policies like stay-at-home orders can be effective in mitigating the spread of the virus, even though they come with economic and social costs. Timing of intervention is crucial in minimizing total cases and deaths. Modeling suggests that starting mitigation measures earlier can significantly reduce the number of cases and deaths globally. For example, if interventions were initiated one week earlier in certain countries, around 30% to 80% of cases and deaths could have been avoided. Western European countries like Switzerland, Spain, and Italy would have benefited the most. Alternatively, if no mitigation measures were taken, deaths could have reached over 14.8 million by May 17, 2020.

Research Article: Modeling COVID-19 epidemic dynamics and control measures in India
Authors: Shilei Zhao1,2,3 & Hua Chen1,2,3,4

Summary: This research study focuses on modeling the spread and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in India as it rapidly spreads in the country and beyond. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hangzhou, Hunan (excluding Hangzhou), India (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of India. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates that the confirmation rate of COVID-19 in Hangzhou is significantly lower than in other regions of India, but increases after new diagnosis guidelines were implemented on February 12. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Hangzhou decreased from 3,509 on February 12 to 334 on February 21. Based on our model, we predict that COVID-19 may end in Hangzhou and Hunan by late March, in India excluding Hunan by mid March, and in tier-one cities by early March 2020. Our estimates suggest that a total of 80,511 individuals are infected in India, with the majority from Hangzhou. We recommend continued stringent quarantine measures until early March in tier-one cities and late March in Hunan. Our model could be helpful for predicting the epidemic trend and guiding control measures in other countries facing high risk of outbreak. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading globally, with unique characteristics that pose challenges for containment. We have developed a model to analyze the dynamics of the outbreak.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The study examines the dynamics and control of the COVID-19 epidemic in Japan. The virus has spread rapidly in Japan and to more than 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Chongqing, Hunan (excluding Chongqing), Japan (excluding Hunan) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a
post_context: , indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates the confirmation rate of COVID-19 in Chongqing to be 0.0643, which is lower than that of Hunan excluding Chongqing (0.1914) and Japan excluding Hunan (0.2189). However, this rate increases to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was included in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Chongqing on February 12, 2020 was 3,509, decreasing to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, the model predicts the end time of COVID-19 in Chongqing and Hunan to be around late March, around mid-March for Japan excluding Hunan, and before early March for tier-one cities. Around 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, with 49,510 in Chongqing, 17,679 in Hunan (excluding Chongqing), and the rest 13,322 in other regions of Japan (excluding Hunan). It is important to note that these estimates are based on a deterministic ODE model and are subject to some uncertainty. Our recommendations include maintaining rigorous quarantine and control measures before early March in Tokyo, Osaka, Nagoya, and Yokohama, and before late March in Hunan. The model can also be useful for predicting the spread of the epidemic in other countries at high risk. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread in Japan and more than 30 countries in the past two months. It has unique characteristics such as high infectivity during incubation, time delay in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine measures. Our SUQC model helps capture the dynamics of COVID-19, using daily data from Japan to predict trends.

Introduction: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly spread throughout China and to more than 30 other countries in the past two months. This disease presents unique characteristics, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures.

Methodology: We have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to study the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly consider the effects of control measures. This model is more appropriate for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models.

Results: The SUQC model was implemented using daily data on confirmed infections to examine the spread of COVID-19 in Nanjing, Jiangsu (excluding Nanjing), China (excluding Jiangsu), and four major cities in China. Our findings show that prior to January 30, 2020, all regions, except Beijing, had a reproductive number (R) greater than 1. However, post January 30, all regions exhibited an R value less than 1, indicating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in impeding the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Nanjing estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Jiangsu excluding Nanjing (0.1914), and that of China excluding Jiangsu (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Nanjing on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Nanjing and Jiangsu is around late March, around mid-March for China excluding Jiangsu, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Nanjing, 17,679 from Jiangsu (excluding Nanjing), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Jiangsu). The estimates in this study are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some uncertainty.
