text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The global impact of the COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has affected both public health and economy on a worldwide scale. This study was conducted by researchers from various institutions in Brazil, focusing on agent-based simulation and epidemic models to analyze the situation.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Thus, it serves as a valuable tool for politicians and health authorities to strategically plan their response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The outbreak, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, was first identified in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was on February 25th, 2020. The country has since been severely impacted, with over 1.2 million confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths recorded as of June 26th, 2020. The pandemic has had far-reaching effects on all aspects of life, including politics, education, economy, and the environment. The most effective strategy to combat the outbreak has been implementing strict social distancing measures, as supported by various studies. Many countries have adopted such measures to varying degrees of success, highlighting the challenge of predicting the outcomes due to the complexity of societies.

pre_context: The model in Algorithm 1 represents an agent-based approach that simulates the epidemiological or economic effects of the pandemic. Each agent's internal state at time t is a combination of the internal states of all agents, with different actions taken based on their type and parameters. The simulation checks for contact between agents based on a distance threshold, with contact resulting in either epidemiological (for type A1 agents) or economic (A1 and A3 agents) effects. The method's complexity is O(n^2), where n is the number of agents, due to calculating the distance between all pairs of agents per iteration.3.1. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: While the initial model lacked accuracy in representing economic dynamics due to its reliance on epidemiological response variables, the incorporation of social constructs and periodic routines greatly enhanced simulation feasibility and improved economic response variable performance. These social constructs and periodic routines are pre-programmed but can be customized by users. The model offers significant flexibility through adjustable parameters that can scale from a single community to an entire country. The experimental methodology section discusses the evaluation of the approach using seven scenarios that simulate different social distancing interventions. The ABS model was implemented in Python version 3.6 and housed in the COVID_ABS package, with source code available at provided links. Each scenario evaluates the impact of a specific social distancing policy using parameters detailed in Table 2, with results summarized in Table 3. Each scenario ran 35 executions with 1,440 iterations each.Since each iteration corresponds to one hour, each exe- cution covers exactly 2 months and one complete accounting cy- cle for houses, government and business, with one salary and tax payment, which occur in the 30th day of the month. The monthly "accounting" event is important for A 2, A 3 and A 4 agents due to its severe cash impact and wealth transfers among agents. The main goal of social interventions is to minimize the death curve D t . It is directly related to flattening the infection curve I t , in order to keep
post_context: t  cases below the critical limit of the healthcare system β 11 .Reducing the I t curve involves reducing the peak infection level I P, as defined in Eq. (9), and extending the time T IP needed to reach this peak, as defined in Eq. (10). The maximum of I t within the range of 1 to T is considered the severe level I S I P, as shown in Eq. (9).

Model selection analysis for an SEIR and an SIR model We used both SEIR and SIR frameworks to model the COVID-19 epidemic in Hubei, China, and we applied model selection analysis to decide which framework is more parsimonious. 3.1. The models In our SIR and SEIR models, the compartment S denotes the susceptible population in Hubei, China, compartment
post_context:
, and R denotes the confirmed cases. The SEIR model includes a latent compartment E for individuals infected but not yet infectious, reflecting the unique latency of COVID-19. This latency is due to a potential 14-day incubation period in which infected individuals are not yet contagious. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, when an individual is infected but not infectious, and the incubation period, when clinical symptoms like fever and coughing appear. While SARS shows individuals become infectious two days after symptoms, COVID-19 evidence suggests they can be contagious before symptoms appear. The SEIR model is more biologically realistic than the SIR model, but requires parameters for the latent period and initial latent population. Both models assume deaths in S, E, and I compartments are minimal during model predictions. Differential equations for each model are given, with calibration using newly confirmed case data.

For COVID-19, it has been observed that individuals can spread the virus before showing symptoms, but the duration of the latent period remains uncertain. The SEIR model is more biologically accurate than the SIR model, but it requires two additional unknown parameters - the latent period and initial latent population. Transfer diagrams for both models are displayed in Figure 1, with detailed explanations of all model parameters provided in Tables 1 and 2. Both models assume that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the period of model predictions. By calibrating the models with newly confirmed case data, the death parameter in the R compartment does not impact the fitting process. When the mean of a Poisson or negative binomial distribution is large, it approximates a normal distribution. The mayor of Shanghai announced on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city, prompting us to estimate the total population in Shanghai on January 22 to be around 6 million. We utilized the same prior distributions for both the SIR and SEIR models and employed the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm to determine posterior distributions for the estimated parameters. The best-fit values and 95% credible intervals were obtained from these posterior distributions and are presented in Tables 1 and 2 for the SIR and SEIR models, respectively. Comparing the two models, we calculated the AICc values to be 174 for SIR and 186 for SEIR, indicating a significant loss of information when using the SEIR model. Consequently, our analysis will focus on the SIR model. Furthermore, our calibration results revealed a linkage between the transmission rate, b, and the diagnosis rate, r, suggesting a nonidentifiability issue which is illustrated in Figure 2.

author: enrique
pre_context: Data for model calibration can be gathered from various sources, such as technical, surveillance, or administrative data, as well as published literature. However, this process can be challenging during outbreaks of novel pathogens, like SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19 pandemic. To address this, we employed advanced inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce the wide confidence intervals typically seen in such situations. Through Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, we were able to achieve this goal. Our baseline predictions for Hubei, China were generated by sampling the posterior distribution to create prediction intervals. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals based on newly confirmed cases reported from January 21 to February 4, 2020, during the lockdown in Hubei, China. These projections illustrate the potential trajectory of the epidemic in Hubei, China if additional control measures were not implemented after March 8. Figures 4(a) and (b) present the distributions of projected peak time and estimates of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Hubei, China together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after March 8 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 8.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our calculations, if strict quarantine measures were not implemented after March 8, the number of peak cases in Hubei, China would have been around 120,000, and the epidemic would have lasted until mid-May 2020.

post_context: We will estimate the impact of the more restrictive control measures in Section 6. The prediction intervals for the diagnosis rate r in Shenzhen were initially calculated over a wide credible interval of 0.0637 to 0.909, taking into account various assumptions about the case-infection ratio and the scale of the epidemic. Further analysis was conducted by narrowing the parameter r into three ranges: 0.02 to 0.03, 0.05 to 0.1, and 0.2 to 1. The SIR model was then recalibrated for each range of r, leading to different predictions for newly confirmed cases, as depicted in Figure 5. The graph shows model predictions for the progression of the COVID-19 epidemic in Shenzhen, starting from January 21, 2020, for the three different ranges of the diagnosis rate r: 0.02 to 0.03, 0.05 to 0.1, and 0.2 to 1.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In the agent-based model Covasim for COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, the duration of symptoms and viral shedding varies but generally increases with severity. Recovery times differ for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases as outlined in Table 1. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or succumb, with death probability linked to age (Table 2). Transmission occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious person, with a probability of transmission (β). In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of about 4–6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2–2.7, depending on population size, age distribution, and other factors. The default β value of 0.016 in Covasim was calibrated using data from Washington and Oregon.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These values have been chosen with a relative weight of 10:2:2:1 to align with time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types. This weighting aims to have a mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In a typical transmission scenario without interventions, approximately 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions, such as physical distancing, can modify the value of β. Individual infectiousness and disease severity can vary over time, with viral load used to model these differences. Studies have shown that viral load peaks around or just before symptom onset and then decreases. We model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, the high stage is set to be twice as high as the low stage and lasts for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each individual is determined by a negative binomial distribution with a mean of 1.0 and a shape parameter of 0.45. This distribution is consistent with international estimates and data from Washington state and Oregon. The daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for individuals. A representative sample of individuals with default parameter values is shown in Fig 2.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim, a model of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporates varying durations of symptoms and viral shedding, which tend to increase with severity. The model distinguishes between recovery times for asymptomatic, mildly symptomatic, and severely symptomatic individuals (Table 1). Generally, non-critical cases recover, while critical cases may recover or result in death, with the likelihood of death rising with age (Table 2). In terms of transmission and viral dynamics within hosts, the probability of virus transmission, represented by β, is triggered when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 daily contacts per person, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of around 2.2-2.7, influenced by factors such as population size and age distribution. The default value of β = 0.016 in Covasim is derived from calibrations to data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Interventions such as physical distancing can modify the value of β. Individual differences in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness are taken into account by modeling variations in viral load. Studies have shown that viral load is highest around symptom onset, followed by a decline. We model two stages of viral load: an early high stage lasting for up to 4 days and a longer low stage. The default viral load for each individual is determined using a negative binomial distribution with a mean of 1.0 and shape parameter of 0.45. author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, users must adjust this parameter to align with local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. The value of β varies depending on the contact type when realistic network structures (e.g. households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) are considered. Default transmission probabilities are approximately 0.050 in households, 0.010 in workplaces and schools, and 0.005 in the community. These values, with relative weightings of 10:2:2:1, were selected to match time-use surveys and previous studies, resulting in a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In a typical (unmitigated) transmission scenario, the distribution of transmission events across contact layers is roughly 30% through households, 25% through workplaces, 15% through schools, and 30% through the community. Interventions like physical distancing can also impact the value of β. Furthermore, we account for variability in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and individual infectiousness levels using individual viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54–58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state. The daily viral load is utilized to adjust the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual on a specific day. Viral loads for a selection of people with default parameter values are displayed in Fig 2. The distribution of transmissions among asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary depending on the situation, with estimated proportions for Seattle provided in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is reduced if the infected individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we offer a parameter that can be adjusted based on the modeling requirements or situation, recognizing that some studies suggest much lower levels of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].
